newsitem.title: FRANCE: French journalists to strike over tax break threat.
newsitem.headline: French journalists to strike over tax break threat.

text.p: France's main journalism unions called on their members on Monday to stage a 24-hour strike on October 15 over a government plan to raise their taxes.

The six largest journalist unions urged media workers to gather in front of the National Assembly to press their demand for withdrawal of the plan, which would end a 30 percent tax rebate they have enjoyed for five decades.
The rebate carries a ceiling of 50,000 francs ($10,000).
They argue the tax hike will also threaten the survival of already financially-strapped media companies by forcing them to raise salaries to compensate for the loss in take-home pay.
In other protests, journalists in some regions announced plans, dubbed "Operation Invisible Man", to refuse coverage of local parliamentarians who vote in favour of the tax hike.

Prime Minister Alain Juppe's government has proposed ending tax breaks for professions including fashion models and health care workers to cut state deficits and help France qualify for a single European currency from 1999.
